newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel economic activity rises in May, June.
newsitem.headline: Israel economic activity rises in May, June.

text.p: Economic activity in Israel rose in the months of May and June, the Central Bureau of Statistics said in a summary of recently published economic indicators issued on Monday.
The main economic indicators for these months show that industrial production and imports of production inputs rose along with a more moderate rise in private consumption.
The indicators show a continued slowdown in the growth of industrial exports and a slight increase in the trade deficit.
Unemployment was also higher in the two months, the bureau said.

Industrial production in April-May rose by an annualised five to six percent, compared with a rise of two to three percent in February-March having been unchanged in the September 1996-January 1997 period.
Imports of production inputs rose in the March-June period by six to seven percent, after a three percent rise in February and continued falls in imports in the previous months since February 1996.
Retail sales rose in June by an annualised 10 percent, after rises of 13 percent in the previous three months.
In January-June the number of tourist arrivals by air was only slightly higher than arrivals in the second half of 1996.
Exports of goods, excluding diamonds and exports from the West Bank and Gaza Strip, rose in June by an annualised three to four percent, after a rise of five percent in May.

The trade deficit, excluding diamonds, ships and aircraft, rose in June to $518 million after having fallen continuously since February last year. In January-February 1996 the deficit was close to $780 million a month.
Data on the consumer price indices shows that in the months of April-June prices rose by an annualised eight to nine percent, against rises of about 10 percent in the months of January-March.
Unemployment in May was 7.7 percent against 7.6 percent in April and 7.5 percent in March.
